column5: it is the capital of the modern Faiyum Governorate. Originally called Shedet in Egyptian
column6: the Greeks called it Koinē Greek: Κροκοδειλόπολις
column9: romanized: Arsinoë. It is one of Egypt's oldest cities due to its strategic location.

column1: Its name in English is also spelled as Fayum
column2: Faiyum or Al Faiyūm. Faiyum was previously officially named Madīnet Al Faiyūm (Arabic for The City of Faiyum). The name Faiyum (and its spelling variations) may also refer to the Faiyum Oasis
column3: although it is commonly used by Egyptians today to refer to the city.The modern name of the city comes from Coptic  ̀Ⲫⲓⲟⲙ /Ⲡⲉⲓⲟⲙ epʰiom/peiom (whence the proper name Ⲡⲁⲓⲟⲙ payom)
column4: meaning the Sea or the Lake
column5: which in turn comes from late Egyptian pꜣ-ym of the same meaning
column6: a reference to the nearby Lake Moeris; the extinct elephant ancestor Phiomia was named after it.

column1: Archaeological evidence has found occupations around the Fayum dating back to at least the Epipalaeolithic. Middle Holocene occupations of the area are most widely studied on the north shore of Lake Moeris
column2: where Gertrude Caton Thompson and Elinor Wight Gardner did a number of excavations of Epipalaeolithic and Neolithic sites
column3: as well as a general survey of the area. Recently the area has been further investigated by a team from the UCLA/RUG/UOA Fayum Project.In ancient Egypt
column4: the city was called Shedet. It was the most significant centre of the cult of the crocodile god Sobek (borrowed from the Demotic pronunciation as Koinē Greek: Σοῦχος Soûkhos
column5: and then into Latin as Suchus). In consequence
column6: the Greeks called it "Crocodile City" (Koinē Greek: Κροκοδειλόπολις Krokodeilópolis)
column7: which was borrowed into Latin as Crocodīlopolis. The city worshipped a tamed sacred crocodile called in Koine Petsuchos
column9: that was adorned with gold and gem pendants. The Petsoukhos lived in a special temple pond and was fed by the priests with food provided by visitors. When Petsuchos died

column2: the city was for a while called Ptolemais Euergétis (Koinē Greek: Πτολεμαῒς Εὐεργέτις). Ptolemy II Philadelphus (309–246 BC) renamed the city Arsinoë and the whole nome after the name of his sister-wife Arsinoe II (316–270 or 268)
column3: who was deified after her death as part of the Ptolemaic cult of Alexander the Great
column4: the official religion of the kingdom.Under the Roman Empire
column5: Arsinoë became part of the province of Arcadia Aegypti. To distinguish it from other cities of the same name

column2: Arsinoë became the seat of a bishopric
column4: the capital of the province and the metropolitan see. Michel Le Quien gives the names of several bishops of Arsinoë
column5: nearly all of them associated with one heresy or another.The Catholic Church
column6: considering Arsinoë in Arcadia to be no longer a residential bishopric
column7: lists it as a titular see.Fayyum was the seat of Shahralanyozan
column8: governor of the Sasanian Egypt (619–629).The 10th-century Bible exegete
column10: thought el-Fayyum to have actually been the biblical city of Pithom
column12: the region became the subject of the most detailed government survey to survive from the medieval Arab world

column1: Faiyum is the source of some famous death masks or mummy portraits painted during the Roman occupation of the area. The Egyptians continued their practice of burying their dead
column2: despite the Roman preference for cremation. While under the control of the Roman Empire
column3: Egyptian death masks were painted on wood in a pigmented wax technique called encaustic—the Faiyum mummy portraits represent this technique. While previously believed to represent Greek settlers in Egypt
column4: modern studies conclude that the Faiyum portraits instead represent mostly native Egyptians
column5: reflecting the complex synthesis of the predominant Egyptian culture and that of the elite Greek minority in the city.
